TODO - Change title image.
TODO - Add links to items (easy to make affiliate links??).
Babies need a lot of stuff. Okay, they don't
a lot of stuff, but they do need some things to keep them safe, warm, fed, and healthy. And some products make your life as parents easier, which
to help you estimate the costs of the baby's first year of life. It helps break down common baby purchases based on survey of BabyCenter parents and their research.
There are items BabyCenter lists that we'll cover in other articles that I exclude from the calculator:
- including diaper setup costs (diaper pails, changing pads, etc.)
Feeding (to be written) - cost of food/formula
Removing all of those... your baby's first year may cost:
!?!? That's a pretty big number. What does this include, and how much did we actually spend on this stuff?

on our baby's first year of stuff (most of which we will be able to use for baby #2). We did borrow and were given some items, which we could have purchased ourselves for ~$239 (adding this to what we actually spent = $1,836), so one could reasonably expect to spend ~$2,000. This is about ~30% of what BabyCenter says it will cost. Where's the discrepancy?
Let's break it down by category.
Our Cost with gifts: $81.67 - the value of used clothing and gifts from family/friends is difficult to value

We were fortunate enough to have a family who gave us their hand-me-downs (which were mostly used items for them as well). We had more than enough clothing from these friends, and our family and friends couldn't resist buying additional adorable clothes. Everything is so cute when it's so small!
Not everyone is as lucky as we were, but even if you do need to buy clothing, buying used is
cheaper than new, and it's often in pretty good shape because little babies grow so fast and, well, mostly just lay there. So the Clothing category is a good place to cut costs.
We did buy a few clothes (mostly used). Here's what we actually spent:
40% off - this was definitely a splurge though
Teenage mutant ninja turtle onesie and pineapple costume. Could have done this for cheaper but my sister talked me into it :)
With a strap, so they don't fall off. Little man ended up hating these and wore them like 3 times. Oh well...
TODO: Add pics - Taco bout cute, dinosaur?
I joined a "free baby swap" group on Facebook. Here's the group description:
"This is a FREE swap for baby, kid, and other gear/items in the <city> area - no buying, selling, or trading allowed within the group."

This is a great idea - people post things their kid doesn't need anymore (grew out of, never liked, etc.), and people who need it arrange for pickup and it gets a new, free life. We've gotten a few fun toys this way, and gifted some of the hand-me-downs that didn't work for us.

People are very generous in these groups, posting large boxes of clothing that would set you up with everything your baby needs for various ages. There is a bit of work involved to look for items you need and pick them up. Because of groups like this, even if we hadn't had a hand-me-down source of clothing, I believe we could have spent very little on clothing in our baby's first year.
I'm not sure exactly what's included in their estimate, but our little guy was rarely sick, since we were able to stay home with him most of the time. There are few medical items that came in handy:
Great for stuffy noses. Used half a bottle in the first year for the handful of times baby was sick.
Equate (Walmart) brand. Only used a handful of times, mostly after vaccines or while teething.

We wanted a new, faster thermometer so we would be confident about measuring baby's temperature when we was really little. It also can be used rectally, which is important for newborns. We're happy with this one; it's also a

(See below for NoseFrida gift we received.) NoseFrida says you should use a new filter for every use. We found that's not really necessary - they often don't actually get dirty, and you can hand wash them in soapy water several times before they would degrade. So we didn't really end up needing all of these (still have some left at his 2nd birthday).
, breastfed babies are supposed to get vitamin D supplements until they can get it from other parts of their diet.
Baby's skin is extra sensitive, so we bought special sunscreen. Only recommended for use after baby is 6 months old!
we were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):
. This was really helpful for us when baby had a cold - it helped him breathe much better.

Notably, we did not purchase any diaper cream in the first year of baby's life. Our baby hardly ever had diaper rash, and when he did we just used our samples from free baby registry bags and the doctor's office. We did frequently use Vaseline as a moisture barrier down there when he was starting to tinge a little pink (included in the

properties.ariaLabel: baby safety kits   not worth it permalink

children.value: Baby safety kits - not worth it
An obvious (to me, now) area where I don't think it's worth spending the $$ is "baby safety kits", with 20-30 pieces of "health items".
, "You’ll never use all that crap. I promise."
Here's a rough breakdown of what's included:
Hospital gave us one of these, but an old toothbrush also works. Could also buy separately for $5.
You'll want a higher quality product
NoseFrida is way better; we never used the nasal aspirator they gave us at the hospital
You want to be confident you have a good, fast thermometer - this one might be fine but we preferred a brand name thermometer
You won't need a toothbrush until your baby has teeth (maybe even after the first year - wiping them with a wet washcloth was fairly effective). We like
We used a tiny syringe they gave us at the hospital. Our infant acetaminophen also came with its own dispensing syringe.
You probably already have these in a first aid kit. Our doctor also gave us ~20 at our first visit.
Baby likely won't have enough hair to actually need a brush/comb, and when they do you can just use a comb/brush you have, or the cradle cap brush.
We didn't really use our emery boards because baby's nails were too soft
Useless (use a piece of paper or your smartphone)
So, for $30, you can buy a much higher quality set of items that you'll actually use: NoseFrida ($15), high-quality thermometer ($10), and nail clippers ($4).
Our Cost with gifts: $6.22 (only included items actually used in first year)
We basically used this as a catch-all lotion/diaper cream. Slather it on after baths or when his bottom starts to look a little pink as a protective barrier.
we were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):
Baby Magic hair and body wash (2 pack)
. My husband's family swears by the smell of this stuff. Little guy likes that it makes bubbles :) We used less than one bottle in a year.
Baby bath gift set (shampoo, soap, lotion)
. We didn't actually use this in the 1st year since we had plenty of Baby Magic and used Vaseline as lotion, but we plan to this year.
I'm not sure what brand or how much baby soap/lotion you need to use to spend $20/month, but we clearly didn't. Honestly, my husband and I together
spend $20/year on toiletries (but we're pretty minimalistic).
~40 board books - anything you can fit in the bag is $6. These are retired library books, but we love them as much as our new books. And I don't feel bad when they get destroyed.
Hallmark going out of business sale
Winnie the Pooh rattle and very cute elephant
Boulder County used baby gear sale
As much for us as they are for him - should be useful for many years
Little baby toys: Crinkly elephant, teething rings, rattle, owl, links (things for baby to look at and put in their mouth)
Stacking cups, ring tower, misc 6-12M toys
Boulder County used baby gear sale
Rainbow Fish bath book, shape sorter toy
We were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):

Hungry Caterpillar, Pout Pout Fish, Chick Chicka Boom Boom, 1st 100 Words, Doggies, Dear Zoo, Richard Scary, etc. We love to read these, but probably don't need them, so not included in the total above.

This is an area where it's easy to get carried away, since your baby loves new things and you like to make them happy. But realistically, we didn't need to purchase that many toys (plus, these are popular gifts). For example, our baby's favorite toys for a long time were a bunch of used tennis balls from my brother - not bouncy enough to play real tennis with anymore but plenty entertaining for an infant. And rocks. We still like rocks.
Chicco Keyfit30 as part of the
. Technically, we didn't even buy this until after baby's first year, since he was short and didn't need it yet. But I'll include it here since most babies need a bigger car seat around age 1.
Wirecutter's upgrade stroller pick, the UPPAbaby Cruz
is $550, with its sister model, the
, coming in at $970. We opted for the

, which came as part of a travel system with our car seat. We couldn't convince ourselves that any other stroller could be worth an extra $400. If we were going for higher-end, I would have looked harder at the
- "the UPPABaby Vista, but for much less!"
We anticipated having another baby, but decided to punt this purchase until later, and I'm glad we did.
Our car seat snapped into our stroller, so we didn't buy this.
We never had plans to jog with baby, so we didn't buy one. If we do want one with more suspension, I'll likely look on Craigslist.
Bought a used Pack 'n Play with a bassinet insert and reversible napper/diaper changer (like
) at a JBF used baby gear sale. Includes cost of 2 sheets. These are fairly easy to find used.

Bought a used Kelty hiking backpack at a used baby sale. It doesn't have all the bells and whistles, but it does have a sunshade and baby and dad like it. We don't use it super often or for long hikes, and it works for us.
Bought a Baby K'tan used at a
sale. By far my favorite way to wear baby when he was little.
We repurposed a regular Jansport backpack for diapers. It doesn't have perfect pockets for everything, but it works and holds a lot of stuff.

BabyCenter doesn't list this here, but many parents end up with extra strollers/car seats/car seat bases for convenience. We frequently visit some friends an airplane ride away, and they store an extra Chicco Keyfit 30 and Chicco Bravo stroller for us so we don't have to travel with it (paid $50 used, ~$400 new). It also came with 2 bases ($85 new), so we use the extra one in our other car. We also purchased an extra pack n' play to keep at the grandparents' house ($15, including 2 sheets).
We were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):
A generous coworker gave us her old ErgoBaby 360. I've seen these used fairly frequently as well, so probably could have purchased one for ~$50.

This is definitely the most expensive category, with lots of expensive (~$100+ new) items. But clearly, there are lots of places that you can save $$ here (~$1000 to be exact), either by skipping purchases completely or buying used. I don't regret any of our decisions here.
We were gifted or borrowed (not included in "our cost" total above):
Borrowed from a friend between babies. Could have gotten a free one from my baby swap Facebook group.
Borrowed from a friend between babies. Could have gotten a free one from my baby swap Facebook group.
Gifted a used one. Could have picked one up used for $5, or free maybe.
Gifted a used one. Could have picked one up used for $5, or free maybe.

This is a category in which we saved a lot of $$ (and space!) by borrowing from friends with off-cycle babies. Many of these are also only used by babies for <3 months, so they're typically easy to find used for free or cheap.
We hardly used the bouncer - I wouldn't buy one again.
We didn't buy a dedicated changing table - just used the a changing pad on top of the dresser (listed below).
Scored a quality (Dutalier) one in good shape on Craiglist by setting up an alert.
Had an extra laundry hamper that went in baby's room. But this shouldn't be more than $5-10.
(gifted 1 crib sheet). Not used on the bed, but also purchased 3 Carter's blankets and 3 Aden & Anais muslin swaddle blankets used for $10.
actually make it harder for your baby to sleep
from the people who lived in our house before us, ~$50. New: $250. Also bought some
Framed art and rug from a Hallmark going-out-of-business sale.
, bought on sale with coupon. This was a
We were gifted or borrowed (not included in "our cost" total above):
from a friend between babies that we used in our room until baby moved to his crib. I could have picked up a free one from my Facebook baby swap group if necessary.

I'm not sure why this is listed separately - the "co-sleeper" we used is basically a 2-in-1 bassinet/co-sleeper. I do think they make specialized gear so the baby can sleep in the bed with you, so maybe it's that?

This seemed like an unnecessary expense to us. It may make the nursery look really nice, but the baby can't sleep with anything but a crib sheet anyway. My mom did sew us a crib skirt and some matching curtains, which look very nice. Fabric was maybe $20? We were also gifted a new crib sheet (mentioned above) - those usually run $10 new at Target.
We used a lamp my mom kept from my childhood bedroom, but could have used any lamp.
Essentially, you need a bassinet (or pack 'n play, listed in the

category), crib, mattress, and some sort of dresser. We puchased an inexpensive crib (Ikea) that we think looks good, but you can spend up to $1,000 on these. We also saved $$ by skipping the dedicated changing table, as our dresser works great. We also really like our rocker and some sort of video baby monitor. Everything else can be scaled up or down to your preference - the baby won't care if everything is matching/cute.
from a JBF sale. We also used samples from registry gift bags.
We got a free used high chair that we use most of the time. If we had purchased this, probably would have gotten this
with an extra seat for $35 (new: $90), which we use at restaurants and friends' houses.
Got some hand-me-downs from a friend, and bought 20 spoons/forks from a used baby sale to supplement.
Bought a set of 6 colorful plastic bowls on clearance at Safeway. My sister gave me some old plastic plates she still had.
Bumkin Sleeved Winnie the Pooh bib
. These are way easier to clean than cloth bibs.
(used) - helps baby suck on things (he loves ice cubes?) without worrying about choking.
We were gifted or borrowed (not included in "our cost" total above):

Gifted a weighted straw Munchkin cup and 2 hand-me-down Nuby sippy cups (tilt kind). We found that leftover (free) plastic taster cups from beer festivals are a great way to practice open cup drinking.
My mom bought some on-sale fabric and sewed it into burp cloths.
Already mentioned above - our primary high chair was gifted to us.
Already mentioned above - we had ~15 spoons gifted to us.

Babies don't need most of this stuff until they're 4-6M old. The biggest expense (high chair) can be fairly easily minimized. We're fairly minimialistic here, and it's been fine. We didn't end up doing much bottle feeding, and didn't have to try lots of types of bottles, so that helped.
I don't think this is fair to list, as most health insurance covers a breast pump. Mine covered a
. I did spend $8.49 on replacement valves, which insurance didn't cover.
in the early days. I borrowed a different
for traveling once, but it never really worked that well for me so I didn't buy one.
Milk storage bags, breast pads, extra breast shields, ice packs
Gifted extra milk storage bags and disposable breast pads. Purchased
for 4 bottles at used baby sale for $5.
We were gifted or borrowed (not included in "our cost" total above):
Listed above - gifted extra milk storage bags (~$15) and disposable breast pads (~$10).
The hoods are cute. But a regular towel works just fine too :)

We just use one of my husband's combs to comb his hair. The hospital gave us a cradle cap soft brush to help wash his hair when he was little, but a washcloth or old toothbrush probably would have worked just fine.
We were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):
. This tub fits in our (giant) kitchen sink. Our little guy outgrew it at 7M (tried to climb out of it). A sponge (
) probably would have worked just fine as well. These are easy to find used because they're big and don't last long.
My mom cut up some old terry cloth she had into washcloth sized squares and that worked well. They're not as adorable, but they work. You can also use adult washcloths.
. We also bought some emery boards at

. Clipping baby's nails is scary - they're so little, so filing might seem like a good option. Our little guy's nails were too soft to file (instead of clipping), so these didn't end up being that useful. Probbaly wouldn't bother with this.
8 kitchen cabinet locks, 10 new tamper-proof outlets, 4 outlet covers (for plugged-in items). Got hand-me-down outlet plugs.
) $30 (new: $70), both used. Hand-me-down gates for other stairs.
Mostly used hand-me-downs or free samples, but forgot pacifiers on one overnight trip to Grandma & Grandpa's house
Costco - 25 cards/envelopes, mostly handed to relatives (instead of mailing)
Baby book and 1st year calendar. 80% off at Hallmark going-out-of-business sale. Didn't really write in these that much - the calendar more than the book.
Used T-Mobile Tuesdays free Walgreens prints when they were available. Did buy some Christmas gifts for grandparents (photo books, etc.,) but we don't count that as a baby cost.
- nice to have for peace of mind (~$10) and
we were gifted (not included in "our cost" total above):
Already mentioned above - hand-me-down gate for stairs. Would have bought 1 additional used one.
Already mentioned above - hand-me-down pacifiers. Would have bought 1 additional 2-pack of soothie-style pacifiers.
But... you got so many things for free! TODO
